segment.source: ListView and GridView UI optimization
segment.target: ListView and GridView UI optimization

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: For more details, see the //build/ session Dramatically Increase Performance when Users Interact with Large Amounts of Data in GridView and ListView.
segment.target: For more details, see the //build/ session Dramatically Increase Performance when Users Interact with Large Amounts of Data in GridView and ListView.

segment.source: Improve **ListView** and **GridView** performance and startup time through UI virtualization, element reduction, and progressive updating of items.
segment.target: Improve **ListView** and **GridView** performance and startup time through UI virtualization, element reduction, and progressive updating of items.

segment.source: For data virtualization techniques, see ListView and GridView data virtualization.
segment.target: For data virtualization techniques, see ListView and GridView data virtualization.

segment.source: Two key factors in collection performance
segment.target: Two key factors in collection performance

segment.source: Manipulating collections is a common scenario.
segment.target: Manipulating collections is a common scenario.

segment.source: A photo viewer has collections of photos, a reader has collections of articles/books/stories, and a shopping app has collections of products.
segment.target: A photo viewer has collections of photos, a reader has collections of articles/books/stories, and a shopping app has collections of products.

segment.source: This topic shows what you can do to make your app efficient at manipulating collections.
segment.target: This topic shows what you can do to make your app efficient at manipulating collections.

segment.source: There are two key factors in performance when it comes to collections: one is the time spent by the UI thread creating items; the other is the memory used by both the raw data set and the UI elements used to render that data.
segment.target: There are two key factors in performance when it comes to collections: one is the time spent by the UI thread creating items; the other is the memory used by both the raw data set and the UI elements used to render that data.

segment.source: For smooth panning/scrolling, it's vital that the UI thread do an efficient and smart job of instantiating, data-binding, and laying out items.
segment.target: For smooth panning/scrolling, it's vital that the UI thread do an efficient and smart job of instantiating, data-binding, and laying out items.

segment.source: UI virtualization
segment.target: UI virtualization

segment.source: UI virtualization is the most important improvement you can make.
segment.target: UI virtualization is the most important improvement you can make.

segment.source: This means that UI elements representing the items are created on demand.
segment.target: This means that UI elements representing the items are created on demand.

segment.source: For an items control bound to a 1000-item collection, it would be a waste of resources to create the UI for all the items at the same time, because they can't all be displayed at the same time.
segment.target: For an items control bound to a 1000-item collection, it would be a waste of resources to create the UI for all the items at the same time, because they can't all be displayed at the same time.

segment.source:
**ListView**
and **GridView** (and other standard **ItemsControl**-derived controls) perform UI virtualization for you.
segment.target:
**ListView**
and **GridView** (and other standard **ItemsControl**-derived controls) perform UI virtualization for you.

segment.source: When items are close to being scrolled into view (a few pages away), the framework generates the UI for the items and caches them.
segment.target: When items are close to being scrolled into view (a few pages away), the framework generates the UI for the items and caches them.

segment.source: When it's unlikely that the items will be shown again, the framework re-claims the memory.
segment.target: When it's unlikely that the items will be shown again, the framework re-claims the memory.

segment.source: If you provide a custom items panel template (see **ItemsPanel** then make sure you use a virtualizing panel such as **ItemsWrapGrid** and **ItemsStackPanel**.
segment.target: If you provide a custom items panel template (see **ItemsPanel** then make sure you use a virtualizing panel such as **ItemsWrapGrid** and **ItemsStackPanel**.

segment.source: If you use **VariableSizedWrapGrid**, **WrapGrid**, or **StackPanel**, then you will not get virtualization.
segment.target: If you use **VariableSizedWrapGrid**, **WrapGrid**, or **StackPanel**, then you will not get virtualization.

segment.source: The concept of a viewport is critical to UI virtualization because the framework must create the elements that are likely to be shown.
segment.target: The concept of a viewport is critical to UI virtualization because the framework must create the elements that are likely to be shown.

segment.source: In general, the viewport of an **ItemsControl** is the extent of the logical control.
segment.target: In general, the viewport of an **ItemsControl** is the extent of the logical control.

segment.source: For example, the viewport of a **ListView** is the width and height of the ListView element.
segment.target: For example, the viewport of a **ListView** is the width and height of the ListView element.

segment.source: Some panels allow child elements unlimited space, examples being **ScrollViewer** and a **Grid**, with auto-sized rows or columns.
segment.target: Some panels allow child elements unlimited space, examples being **ScrollViewer** and a **Grid**, with auto-sized rows or columns.

segment.source: When a virtualized ItemsControl is placed in a panel like that, it takes enough room to display all of its items, which defeats virtualization.
segment.target: When a virtualized ItemsControl is placed in a panel like that, it takes enough room to display all of its items, which defeats virtualization.

segment.source: Restore virtualization by setting a width and height on the ItemsControl.
segment.target: Restore virtualization by setting a width and height on the ItemsControl.

segment.source: Element reduction per item
segment.target: Element reduction per item

segment.source: Keep the number of UI elements used to render your items to a reasonable minimum.
segment.target: Keep the number of UI elements used to render your items to a reasonable minimum.

segment.source: When an items control is first shown, all the elements needed to render a viewport full of items are created.
segment.target: When an items control is first shown, all the elements needed to render a viewport full of items are created.

segment.source: Also, as items approach the viewport, the framework updates the UI elements in cached item templates with the bound data objects.
segment.target: Also, as items approach the viewport, the framework updates the UI elements in cached item templates with the bound data objects.

segment.source: Minimizing the complexity of the markup inside templates pays off in memory and in time spent on the UI thread, improving responsiveness especially while panning/scrolling.
segment.target: Minimizing the complexity of the markup inside templates pays off in memory and in time spent on the UI thread, improving responsiveness especially while panning/scrolling.

segment.source: The templates in question are the item template (see **ItemTemplate** and the control template of a **ListViewItem** or a **GridViewItem** (the item control template, or **ItemContainerStyle**.
segment.target: The templates in question are the item template (see **ItemTemplate** and the control template of a **ListViewItem** or a **GridViewItem** (the item control template, or **ItemContainerStyle**.

segment.source: The benefit of even a small reduction in element count is multiplied by the number of items displayed.
segment.target: The benefit of even a small reduction in element count is multiplied by the number of items displayed.

segment.source: For examples of element reduction, see Optimize your XAML markup.
segment.target: For examples of element reduction, see Optimize your XAML markup.

segment.source: The default control templates for **ListViewItem** and **GridViewItem** contain a **ListViewItemPresenter** and a **GridViewItemPresenter** element, respectively.
segment.target: The default control templates for **ListViewItem** and **GridViewItem** contain a **ListViewItemPresenter** and a **GridViewItemPresenter** element, respectively.

segment.source: Each of these presenters is a single optimized element that displays complex visuals for focus, selection, and other visual states.
segment.target: Each of these presenters is a single optimized element that displays complex visuals for focus, selection, and other visual states.

segment.source: If you already have custom item control templates (**ItemContainerStyle**, or if in future you edit a copy of an item control template, then we recommend you use a ListViewItemPresenter or a GridViewItemPresenter because those elements will give you optimum balance between performance and customizability in the majority of cases.
segment.target: If you already have custom item control templates (**ItemContainerStyle**, or if in future you edit a copy of an item control template, then we recommend you use a ListViewItemPresenter or a GridViewItemPresenter because those elements will give you optimum balance between performance and customizability in the majority of cases.

segment.source: You customize these presenters by setting properties on them.
segment.target: You customize these presenters by setting properties on them.

segment.source: For example, here's markup that removes the check mark that appears by default when an item is selected, and changes the background color of the selected item to orange.
segment.target: For example, here's markup that removes the check mark that appears by default when an item is selected, and changes the background color of the selected item to orange.

segment.source: There are about 25 properties with self-describing names similar to **SelectionCheckMarkVisualEnabled** and **SelectedBackground**. Should the presenter types prove not to be customizable enough for your use case, you can edit a copy of the ListViewItemExpanded or GridViewItemExpanded control template instead. These can be found in \Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\DesignTime\CommonConfiguration\Neutral\UAP\<version>\Generic\generic.xaml. Be aware that using these templates means trading some performance for the increase in customization.
segment.target: There are about 25 properties with self-describing names similar to **SelectionCheckMarkVisualEnabled** and **SelectedBackground**. Should the presenter types prove not to be customizable enough for your use case, you can edit a copy of the ListViewItemExpanded or GridViewItemExpanded control template instead. These can be found in \Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\DesignTime\CommonConfiguration\Neutral\UAP\<version>\Generic\generic.xaml. Be aware that using these templates means trading some performance for the increase in customization.

segment.source: Update ListView and GridView items progressively
segment.target: Update ListView and GridView items progressively

segment.source: If you're using data virtualization then you can keep **ListView** and **GridView** responsiveness high by configuring the control to render temporary UI elements for the items still being (down)loaded.
segment.target: If you're using data virtualization then you can keep **ListView** and **GridView** responsiveness high by configuring the control to render temporary UI elements for the items still being (down)loaded.

segment.source: The temporary elements are then progressively replaced with actual UI as data loads.
segment.target: The temporary elements are then progressively replaced with actual UI as data loads.

segment.source: Also—no matter where you're loading data from (local disk, network, or cloud)—a user can pan/scroll a **ListView** or **GridView** so rapidly that it's not possible to render each item with full fidelity while preserving smooth panning/scrolling.
segment.target: Also—no matter where you're loading data from (local disk, network, or cloud)—a user can pan/scroll a **ListView** or **GridView** so rapidly that it's not possible to render each item with full fidelity while preserving smooth panning/scrolling.

segment.source: To preserve smooth panning/scrolling you can choose to render an item in multiple phases in addition to using placeholders.
segment.target: To preserve smooth panning/scrolling you can choose to render an item in multiple phases in addition to using placeholders.

segment.source: An example of these techniques is often seen in photo-viewing apps: even though not all of the images have been loaded and displayed, the user can still pan/scroll and interact with the collection.
segment.target: An example of these techniques is often seen in photo-viewing apps: even though not all of the images have been loaded and displayed, the user can still pan/scroll and interact with the collection.

segment.source: Or, for a "movie" item, you could show the title in the first phase, the rating in the second phase, and an image of the poster in the third phase.
segment.target: Or, for a "movie" item, you could show the title in the first phase, the rating in the second phase, and an image of the poster in the third phase.

segment.source: The user sees the most important data about each item as early as possible, and that means they're able to take action at once.
segment.target: The user sees the most important data about each item as early as possible, and that means they're able to take action at once.

segment.source: Then the less important info is filled-in as time allows.
segment.target: Then the less important info is filled-in as time allows.

segment.source: Here are the platform features you can use to implement these techniques.
segment.target: Here are the platform features you can use to implement these techniques.

segment.source: Placeholders
segment.target: Placeholders

segment.source: The temporary placeholder visuals feature is on by default, and it's controlled with the **ShowsScrollingPlaceholders** property.
segment.target: The temporary placeholder visuals feature is on by default, and it's controlled with the **ShowsScrollingPlaceholders** property.

segment.source: During fast panning/scrolling, this feature gives the user a visual hint that there are more items yet to fully display while also preserving smoothness.
segment.target: During fast panning/scrolling, this feature gives the user a visual hint that there are more items yet to fully display while also preserving smoothness.

segment.source: If you use one of the techniques below then you can set ShowsScrollingPlaceholders to false if you prefer not to have the system render placeholders.
segment.target: If you use one of the techniques below then you can set ShowsScrollingPlaceholders to false if you prefer not to have the system render placeholders.

source.pc: Progressive data template updates using x:Phase

target.pc: Progressive data template updates using x:Phase

segment.source: Here's how to use the x:Phase attribute with {x:Bind} bindings to implement progressive data template updates.
segment.target: Here's how to use the x:Phase attribute with {x:Bind} bindings to implement progressive data template updates.

segment.source: Here's what the binding source looks like (this is the data source that we'll bind to).
segment.target: Here's what the binding source looks like (this is the data source that we'll bind to).

segment.source: Here's the markup that DeferMainPage.xaml contains.
segment.target: Here's the markup that DeferMainPage.xaml contains.

segment.source: The grid view contains an item template with elements bound to the Title, Subtitle, and Description properties of the MyItem class.
segment.target: The grid view contains an item template with elements bound to the Title, Subtitle, and Description properties of the MyItem class.

segment.source: Note that x:Phase defaults to 0.
segment.target: Note that x:Phase defaults to 0.

segment.source: Here, items will be initially rendered with just the title visible.
segment.target: Here, items will be initially rendered with just the title visible.

segment.source: Then the subtitle element will be data bound and made visible for all the items and so on until all the phases have been processed.
segment.target: Then the subtitle element will be data bound and made visible for all the items and so on until all the phases have been processed.

segment.source: If you run the app now and pan/scroll quickly through the grid view then you'll notice that as each new item appears on the screen, at first it is rendered as a dark gray rectangle (thanks to the **ShowsScrollingPlaceholders** property defaulting to true), then the title appears, followed by subtitle, followed by description.
segment.target: If you run the app now and pan/scroll quickly through the grid view then you'll notice that as each new item appears on the screen, at first it is rendered as a dark gray rectangle (thanks to the **ShowsScrollingPlaceholders** property defaulting to true), then the title appears, followed by subtitle, followed by description.

source.pc: Progressive data template updates using ContainerContentChanging

target.pc: Progressive data template updates using ContainerContentChanging

segment.source: The general strategy for the **ContainerContentChanging** event is to use Opacity to hide elements that don’t need to be immediately visible.
segment.target: The general strategy for the **ContainerContentChanging** event is to use Opacity to hide elements that don’t need to be immediately visible.

segment.source: When elements are recycled, they will retain their old values so we want to hide those elements until we've updated those values from the new data item.
segment.target: When elements are recycled, they will retain their old values so we want to hide those elements until we've updated those values from the new data item.

segment.source: We use the Phase property on the event arguments to determine which elements to update and show.
segment.target: We use the Phase property on the event arguments to determine which elements to update and show.

segment.source: If additional phases are needed, we register a callback.
segment.target: If additional phases are needed, we register a callback.

segment.source: We'll use the same binding source as for x:Phase.
segment.target: We'll use the same binding source as for x:Phase.

segment.source: Here's the markup that MainPage.xaml contains.
segment.target: Here's the markup that MainPage.xaml contains.

segment.source: The grid view declares a handler to its **ContainerContentChanging** event, and it contains an item template with elements used to display the Title, Subtitle, and Description properties of the MyItem class.
segment.target: The grid view declares a handler to its **ContainerContentChanging** event, and it contains an item template with elements used to display the Title, Subtitle, and Description properties of the MyItem class.

segment.source: To get the maximum performance benefits of using ContainerContentChanging, we don't use bindings in the markup but we instead assign values programmatically.
segment.target: To get the maximum performance benefits of using ContainerContentChanging, we don't use bindings in the markup but we instead assign values programmatically.

segment.source: The exception here is the element displaying the title, which we consider to be in phase 0.
segment.target: The exception here is the element displaying the title, which we consider to be in phase 0.

segment.source: Lastly, here's the implementation of the **ContainerContentChanging** event handler.
segment.target: Lastly, here's the implementation of the **ContainerContentChanging** event handler.

segment.source: This code also shows how we add a property of type RecordingViewModel to MainPage to expose the binding source class from the class that represents our page of markup.
segment.target: This code also shows how we add a property of type RecordingViewModel to MainPage to expose the binding source class from the class that represents our page of markup.

segment.source: As long as you don't have any {Binding} bindings in your data template, then mark the event arguments object as handled in the first phase of the handler to hint to the item that it needn't set a data context.
segment.target: As long as you don't have any {Binding} bindings in your data template, then mark the event arguments object as handled in the first phase of the handler to hint to the item that it needn't set a data context.

segment.source: If you run the app now and pan/scroll quickly through the grid view then you'll see the same behavior as for as for x:Phase.
segment.target: If you run the app now and pan/scroll quickly through the grid view then you'll see the same behavior as for as for x:Phase.

segment.source: Container-recycling with heterogeneous collections
segment.target: Container-recycling with heterogeneous collections

segment.source: In some applications, you need to have different UI for different types of item within a collection.
segment.target: In some applications, you need to have different UI for different types of item within a collection.

segment.source: This can create a situation where it is impossible for virtualizing panels to reuse/recycle the visual elements used to display the items.
segment.target: This can create a situation where it is impossible for virtualizing panels to reuse/recycle the visual elements used to display the items.

segment.source: Recreating the visual elements for an item during panning undoes many of the performance wins provided by virtualization.
segment.target: Recreating the visual elements for an item during panning undoes many of the performance wins provided by virtualization.

segment.source: However, a little planning can allow virtualizing panels to reuse the elements.
segment.target: However, a little planning can allow virtualizing panels to reuse the elements.

segment.source: Developers have a couple of options depending on their scenario: the **ChoosingItemContainer** event, or an item template selector.
segment.target: Developers have a couple of options depending on their scenario: the **ChoosingItemContainer** event, or an item template selector.

segment.source: The ChoosingItemContainer event is the most performant approach.
segment.target: The ChoosingItemContainer event is the most performant approach.

segment.source:
**ChoosingItemContainer**
is an event that allows you to provide an item (**ListViewItem** to the **ListView**/**GridView** whenever a new item is needed during start-up or recycling.
segment.target:
**ChoosingItemContainer**
is an event that allows you to provide an item (**ListViewItem** to the **ListView**/**GridView** whenever a new item is needed during start-up or recycling.

segment.source: You can create a container based on the type of data item the container will display (shown in the example below).
segment.target: You can create a container based on the type of data item the container will display (shown in the example below).

segment.source: ChoosingItemContainer is the most performant way to use different data templates for different items.
segment.target: ChoosingItemContainer is the most performant way to use different data templates for different items.

segment.source: Container caching is something that can be achieved using ChoosingItemContainer.
segment.target: Container caching is something that can be achieved using ChoosingItemContainer.

segment.source: For example, if you have five different template, with one template occurring an order of magnitude more often than the others, then ChoosingItemContainer allows you not only to create items at the ratios needed but also to keep an appropriate number of elements cached and available for recycling.
segment.target: For example, if you have five different template, with one template occurring an order of magnitude more often than the others, then ChoosingItemContainer allows you not only to create items at the ratios needed but also to keep an appropriate number of elements cached and available for recycling.

segment.source:
**ChoosingGroupHeaderContainer**
provides the same functionality for group headers.
segment.target:
**ChoosingGroupHeaderContainer**
provides the same functionality for group headers.

segment.source: An item template selector (**DataTemplateSelector** allows an app to return a different item template at runtime based on the type of the data item that will be displayed.
segment.target: An item template selector (**DataTemplateSelector** allows an app to return a different item template at runtime based on the type of the data item that will be displayed.

segment.source: This makes development more productive, but it makes UI virtualization more difficult because not every item template can be reused for every data item.
segment.target: This makes development more productive, but it makes UI virtualization more difficult because not every item template can be reused for every data item.

segment.source: When recycling an item (**ListViewItem**, the framework must decide whether the items that are available for use in the recycle queue (the recycle queue is a cache of items that are not currently being used to display data) have an item template that will match the one desired by the current data item.
segment.target: When recycling an item (**ListViewItem**, the framework must decide whether the items that are available for use in the recycle queue (the recycle queue is a cache of items that are not currently being used to display data) have an item template that will match the one desired by the current data item.

segment.source: If there are no items in the recycle queue with the appropriate item template then a new item is created, and the appropriate item template is instantiated for it.
segment.target: If there are no items in the recycle queue with the appropriate item template then a new item is created, and the appropriate item template is instantiated for it.

segment.source: If, on other hand, the recycle queue contains an item with the appropriate item template then that item is removed from the recycle queue and is used for the current data item.
segment.target: If, on other hand, the recycle queue contains an item with the appropriate item template then that item is removed from the recycle queue and is used for the current data item.

segment.source: An item template selector works in situations where only a small number of item templates are used and there is a flat distribution throughout the collection of items that use different item templates.
segment.target: An item template selector works in situations where only a small number of item templates are used and there is a flat distribution throughout the collection of items that use different item templates.

segment.source: When there is an uneven distribution of items that use different item templates then new item templates will likely need to be created during panning, and this negates many of the gains provided by virtualization.
segment.target: When there is an uneven distribution of items that use different item templates then new item templates will likely need to be created during panning, and this negates many of the gains provided by virtualization.

segment.source: Additionally, an item template selector only considers five possible candidates when evaluating whether a particular container can be reused for the current data item.
segment.target: Additionally, an item template selector only considers five possible candidates when evaluating whether a particular container can be reused for the current data item.

segment.source: So you should carefully consider whether your data is appropriate for use with an item template selector before using one in your app.
segment.target: So you should carefully consider whether your data is appropriate for use with an item template selector before using one in your app.

segment.source: If your collection is mostly homogeneous then the selector is returning the same type most (possibly all) of the time.
segment.target: If your collection is mostly homogeneous then the selector is returning the same type most (possibly all) of the time.

segment.source: Just be aware of the price you're paying for the rare exceptions to that homegeneity, and consider whether using **ChoosingItemContainer** (or two items controls) is preferable.
segment.target: Just be aware of the price you're paying for the rare exceptions to that homegeneity, and consider whether using **ChoosingItemContainer** (or two items controls) is preferable.
